snippet: I don't exactly regret my initial enthusiasm for Lego Friends. But I do regret my willingness to overlook the doggedness of marketers.
abstract: I don't exactly regret my initial enthusiasm for Lego Friends. But I do regret my willingness to overlook the doggedness of marketers.
lead_paragraph: I just saw my first commercial for those Lego Friends for girls I wrote about here before the holiday, and after my first glimpse of Heartlake City, the new Lego world, I wondered if I'd spoken too soon about my willingness to place my order now. As the new Ladyfig characters in their brightly colored cafe morphed, on screen, into animated creations that looked far more Polly Pocket than Lego Hermione Granger, I cringed a little. Then I took a closer look at the building, with its ice-cream cups, flowers and railings. And it occurred to me that maybe the real problem with Lego, for girls and boys, isn't the gender specificity of the various building sets. It's that there are so many sets for building so many specific things.

headline.main: Should Lego Be Gender-Free — or Just Less Complicated?
